content.description: Probably the most climbed route on Snowflake Wall.  The flake goes straight up the center of the wall then bee lines a touch left on smeary feet to a good ledge. From the ledge, climb the bigger flake to the anchors that are shared with Grab and Go.
content.protection: great gear up to #3 BD C4
content.location: Center of the Wall. Hard to miss.

content.description: Locate the lone bolt on the route (Hence the route name). Start on the slabby moss ridden bottom and veer right to a suitcase handle you can girth hitch. start up the nice crack where you can get a great .75 sized cam pull through the crux clipping "The Loner" and top out below the anchors on a large ledge. Route packs a nice little pump but is short lived.
content.protection: sling, smaller cams, 1 bolt to anchors.
content.location: Located in the center on the somewhat mossy wall to the far right.

content.description: This is a great route and very sequential.  Once you find the sequence the route will feel easier than the grade given. Climb up to the high first bolt, clip. Get your hand in the top part of the moose footprint looking hold, smear your left foot and gun up and left for the mail box slot. Switch feet, smear your right and clip the 2nd bolt grab a very small (once bigger) right hand crimp/side pull crank down and go for the upper ledge.  A couple pieces of placed trad gear will get you to the anchors above the flake.
content.location: 3rd route from the left in the middle of the wall. 2 bolts to gear placements.

content.description: Crux is getting the 2nd bolt clipped. After getting the 2nd hanger clipped find a sequence that gets you to a crimp up and right of the 2nd hanger that will get you to the "Thank God" jug to help you finish the route. Use in cut rails, crimps and good footwork to get you to the anchors which are shared with B.D.R. to the left.
content.protection: 3 bolts to shared anchors with B.D.R.

content.description:
This is hands down the hardest route on the wall. Sequential pockets and crimps along with great footwork is needed to get you through this rather sustained route all the way to the ledge below the anchor. If you are using Snowflake Crack on your left at anytime you are NOT on route.

You MUST have a competent belayer! If YOU the belayer are not paying attention or you have too much slack out and your climber falls moving above the 2nd bolt to the "Thank God" hold which is easier to clip the third bolt from ,they will be down around your head after the fall. As the belayer you don't want a butt helmet.
content.protection: 3 bolts to glue in anchors/quick links.
content.location: Route is located the farthest right on the main wall.

content.description: sport,3 bolts to glue ins/quick link anchors.
content.location: furthest route of left side of wall
